The white's lsb has d7 (very passive), d6 (played in the game, looking for the exchange, or Bb4+, the well-known attack. It should be played after black goes c5, however, or it will be answered with c6, with tempo.

This is "my" move. I simply don't like b5 - Bb4+. It is playable, for sure, but it gives initiative to white.

White felt like this. My answer is already prepared.
Another "loss of tempo". But black wants to keep the pawn chain solid, and the centre closed... until he breaks in with c5.
If white does this, it means he doesn't want to start the bishop's exchange.
My turn to become active. Look at the board: black seems to be playing foolishly, wasting tempo with pawn moves, while his pieces are still undevelopen.
White doesn't seize the initiative. This move makes it difficult to me to develop my dsb.
Finally.
Interesting, and still not attacking. In chess, when you "just wait", normally, the opponent will "do something".
Like this. Suddenly, developement is almost equal. White has to play carefully the developement of his queenside.
This was played to avoid my bishop to take his after a piece goes to d7, but it has a "little" downside...
I open the column.
This is the developement way black choose... over Bd7, and this gives me an idea.
Being axb4 impossible due to QxR.
Interesting.
I take advantage of the fact that white can't play c4, closing the game, because of the bishop. Black created problems in white's developement...
Nxb5 is the good move. But I was thinking: "how to exploit h2", so I thought about Qc7 and some Nxd5 sac (if NxN, Qxh2#). But it's a long road to there.
Bb2 will be a waste of a bishop. But I don't have developed my kingside... we have both of us a complete wing undeveloped... as far as move 13!
